Subject: Application of Cantera for Rocket Propellant Explosions
Message-ID: <am8t8n+4mkr@...>
User-Agent: eGroups-EW/0.82
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Length: 1322
X-Mailer: Yahoo Groups Message Poster
From: "randynyman" <rnyman@...>
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=124844058
X-Yahoo-Profile: randynyman

I'm working on a computer program to simulate the thermodynamic and
chemical composition of liquid propellant fireballs that result from
catastrophic abort of US launch vehicles.  Unlike conventional
controlled combustion in a rocket engine combustion chamber, the abort
mode ruptures the propellant tanks and leads to incomplete mixing and
partial combustion of the fuels and oxidizers.  I'm interested in
simulating both hypergolic propellants and hydrocarbon + LOX
combinations.  To date I have been applying an equilibrium combustion
analysis to an assumed fraction of the fuel+oxidizer mixture and then
adding supplemental reactions to represent thermal decomposition and
vaporization of the residual "unreacted" propellant that are added to
the combustion model products. I have to then evaluate the
thermodynamic state of the mixture in order to compute an average
fireball temperature and heat content.  The heat content drives the
bouyancy of the propellant exhaust cloud which is then embedded into
an atmopsheric physics model to compute downwind transport and
diffusion.  This problem is of interest because the unreacted
propellants are often toxic at even low concentrations.  Any insights
or opinions on how (or if) Cantera might be applied to such a problem?

Randy Nyman, P.E.
ACTA Inc.
Vandenberg AFB
